channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-10320] Avoid ArrayList.iterator() ExplicitColumnTracker
item.description:
I noticed that in a profiler (sampler) run ScanQueryMatcher.setRow(...) showed up at all.
In turns out that the expensive part is iterating over the columns in ExcplicitColumnTracker.reset(). I did some microbenchmarks and found that


private ArrayList<X> l;

...

for (int i=0; i<l.size(); i++) {

   X = l.get(i);

   ...

}

Is twice as fast as:


private ArrayList<X> l;

...

for (X : l) {

   ...

}

The indexed version asymptotically approaches the iterator version, but even at 1m entries it is still faster.
In my tight loop scans this provides for a 5% performance improvement overall when the ExcplicitColumnTracker is used.

Edit:


private X[] l;

...

for (int i=0; i<l.length; i++) {

   X = l[i];

   ...

}

Is even better. Apparently the JVM can even save the boundary check in each iteration.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Simple patch for 0.94.
The


-  private final List<ColumnCount> columns;

+  private final ArrayList<ColumnCount> columns;

is not needed, but it makes it explicit that we're addressing this list via random access.
Interesting finding Lars. +1 on the patch if it gives improvement..

+    for (int i=0; i<this.columns.size(); i++) {

+    	this.columns.get(i).setCount(0);



+    int size = this.columns.size();

+    for (int i=0; i<size; i++) {

+    	this.columns.get(i).setCount(0);

Will that make any difference? I guess compiler will optimize it, but not sure.

Not on JDK7.
In fact it makes it slightly slower(?) Seems bizarre, but in the microbenchmark is does. In all cases I made sure the reference in the ArrayList are actually used, so that the compiler cannot simply optimize them away.

I had also tried a local stack reference rather than a member, that makes no difference.

Didn't try on JDK6 (don't have it on any of my machines at home anymore).

Looks like the JDK is getting smart with multiple threads. In the case where l.size() is part of the loop condition I see more cores doing work.

I need to do some more tests.

At least this explains the strange behavior that precalculating the size is slightly slower. It was actually doing almost twice the amount of work, just on two cores.
I verified that now only one core is used. New patch coming up.

New patch. Makes precalculates length. Insitu in HBase the improvement is even better. The scans appears to have better core locality.
(the microbenchmark confirm that, with the iterator() I see the thread bouncing between cores, doesn't do it with for(...) get(...) loop)
Where should we see the improvement overall? Any way to test it with PE so I can compare with a previous version easily?

Test with 1 scan and with 8 scans (this is a 4 core machine with 2 HTs each).
I see about 4-5% improvement in both cases now.

Lemme do some more tests to make sure. The better core affinity from this patch is surprising.
Spent way too much time on this. Did more tests directly with ExplicitColumnTracker. Going to commit v2. The main part is that it seems more cache line friendly.

Where should we see the improvement overall?

Scanning with ExplicitColumnTracker (i.e. a scan where some columns were added with addColumn) and where all/most data is filtered out at the server (by a filter or a coprocessor).
So in PE the FilteredScanTest might do it. If you run that, let me know what you find. Might be that in all but extreme cases this is just in the noise. I think PE has relatively large columns (1000 bytes), so it might not show.

Will wait with commit until we've had a PE test.

I'd go with what your benchmarks are telling you but came across this recently: "The server compiler likes a loop with an int counter (int i = 0), a constant stride (i++), and loop-invariant limit (i <= n)" and "Loops over arrays work especially well when the compiler can relate the counter limit to the length of the array(s)." from https://wikis.oracle.com/display/HotSpotInternals/PerformanceTechniques

On commit, add comment on why you are doing the 'unusual' pre-sizing before the loop else the next fellow through will think it an unnecessary extra line/task and put it back the way it as previous.

Good one Lars.

Thanks Stack. I wonder whether the same is true for ArrayLists.
That brings to another thought, the columns list is fixed size and never changed once created, so why have an ArrayList at all instead of an Array. Then we can use columns.length in the loop and get this optimization. Will try when I get some time next.
Is this a 0.94 only change or applicable everywhere? (The latter, right?)
v3 does everything array based. In microbenchmarks it's almost 50% faster than v2. Will quantify in situ in a bit.

Nice! I love it!

And to reply to Andrew: Yes, it's the same "issue" in 0.98.

Just ran some micro benchmarks using caliper and I got the following results: https://microbenchmarks.appspot.com/runs/37ac8b21-da30-4694-a9fb-f58592b338f0

Not quite as dramatic as Lars Hofhansl is seeing but still suggests that replacing for(x:y) with array based will be worth it.

Code for benchmark: https://github.com/elliottneilclark/iter-bench
JVM: 


eclark@eclark-MBPr ~/Code/public/iter-bench (master)$ java -version

java version "1.7.0_25"

Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.7.0_25-b15)

Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 23.25-b01, mixed mode)

Thanks Elliott Clark! Looking the code you tested the equivalent of the first patch.
I found later (after JM pointed it out) that ArrayList.size() added more load across the cores did you see this too (and that precalculating the length was better after all)?

Also any chance of trying the same with just arrays (i.e. what -v3 does)?

I pushed a new version of the benchmark code. Here's the results:
https://microbenchmarks.appspot.com/runs/55cd6335-b892-4d4f-83dc-97a4cd2a7e69
Awesome. I'll make a v4 using foreach iteration on the array, that looks nicer and has the same performance it seems.
Nice one..+1.
Final patch. This is the one I'll commit. I'll also make a trunk version.

Unscientific benchmark: 50m rows, 8 byte key, one col (8 byte long value), everything in the cache, everything filtered at the server with a filter.
With patch: 14.2s
Without patch: 15.9s

Same for tunk.

Unless I hear objections I will commit this to all branches (stack, Andrew Purtell).

+1. We have other places in the code base that we should do the same

On trunk I found these that all are core enough to deserve at least a look:
RpcServer#doRunLoop Line 892
HRegion#internalFlushcache: Line 1601
HRegion#doMiniBatchMutation: 2203 (basically all the row lock stuff should be made into arrays.)
HRegionServer#addResult

Thanks Elliott.
I dug around in the read path a bit, didn't see anything else on that side (that stuck out at least).

On the other issues I think the improvement would be eclipsed by the work they're doing (like writing to HDFS or to the network to the client). We should fix those as well. Would prefer a separate issue, though.
Committed to all branches. Thanks for the reviews, and especially to Elliott Clark for the benchmarking.
